hero.title: HEY THERE!
hero.description: I'm Carina an Interface... User Experience... Product... I AM A DESIGNER! Over the past 10 years I worked on cross platform SaaS and E-Commerce for both B2B and B2C. Design lets me help people and satisfies my curiosity along the way. Win win.

values.title: Learning from Users
values.description: Research is a focal point and listening to actual users is the best time investment.

values.title: Learning from Peers
values.description: Collaborating with my team or other experts is important to me. No one knows everything.

values.title: Learning from Media
values.description: Books and podcasts inspire and excite me to trying out new things (please talk to me about OOUX).

quests.title: A design system for all teams
Effortless onboarding with a personalised reward
quests.team: 2 Designers, 1 Product Owner, 6 Developers, 1 Marketing Consultant, 1 Content Consultant

quests.title: Custom lists for self organisation
quests.team: 2 Designers, 1 Product Owner, 6 Developers, 1 Marketing Consultant, 1 Content Consultant

quests.title: A filter for every yogi
quests.team: 1 Product Owner, 2 Designers (UI & UX), 6 Developer, 1 Content consultant

skills.description: In 2015 I started out my career as a UX designer. I chose this profession simply because it brings me joy. I love that, as a designer, I can help people with creativity. When I try to explain what UX is (which is not that rare of an occurrence still) I like to use the metaphor of an architect. When building a house, you first need to figure out what rooms should be in it, and then make sure that visitors find a bathroom quickly they need one.
quests: A design system for all teams
Effortless onboarding with a personalised reward

skills.description: I always like to work very closely with researchers or take on the role myself. I see it as an interglacial part as it is the foundation for all decisions throughout the design process. I find it very exciting to learn something new or surprising or seeing that an idea actually worked. It's the feedback loop that keeps product development going.
quests: A design system for all teams
Effortless onboarding with a personalised reward

skills.description: Prototyping has been a part of my work since the beginning. This is my zen work. I love to sit down, put on some music and just build. Especially since Figma introduced basic logic to their prototyping capabilities it's been even more fun to be able to make a user test feel as realistic as possible (if needed).
quests: Effortless onboarding with a personalised reward

skills.description: I've been doing UI alongside UX since 2021. For me UI is not only making things look nice. It's about conveying specific feelings thats suits the task at hand while staying aligned with brand guidelines and design systems. It's about knowing when to be loud and bold to show the brands colors, and when to quite down and guid the users eye to let them focus on important informations.

OOUX is a design philosophy that respects the fact, that we think in nouns. That our mental modals form around objects. It helps me to understand users and systems more quickly and easily while also being a grate way of collaborating with other roles in the product team. I really enjoy this way of thinking and would love to work on a project that uses the entire process around!
I've been drawing since I can remember. It was always integral to who I am and is one of the first things people learn about me as I like to doodle in meeting (I still pay attention, I swear).

I picked up cubing with a rubiks cube (that thing that was popular in the 80s) when I was around 17 just to see if I can do it. Since then I've not been able to put it down again and my collection has grown to around 20. My best time is 32 sec. which is not super fast but I'm still proud of it.

As someone who is dyslexic I find it important to phrase texts in a clear and easy to understand way, as I know the struggle of overly complicated sentences. This has lead me to put more and more effort and care into the texts I write for interfaces. The impact is easily visible in user tests and always makes me smile.
quests: A design system for all teams
Effortless onboarding with a personalised reward

skills.description: I gathered up quite the suitcase of methods over the years if I do say so myself and appreciate a good flow of them, carefully put together to get to an outcome and output under a shared goal. I'm not the loudest person but passion helps me to get people on board either way.
quests: Effortless onboarding with a personalised reward

inventory.title: The Tipping Point
inventory.author: Malcolm Gladwell
inventory.description: 8/10 - Easy read, real interesting case studies, applicable to personal and professional life.

inventory.title: Flow
inventory.author: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi
inventory.description: 7/10 - The middle part is a bit drawn out but the triggerd reflection and application on ones personal life I find quite valuable.

inventory.title: Thinking Fast and Slow
inventory.author: Daniel Kahneman
inventory.description: 8/10 - A personal accomplishment but not a book for everyone. Powerful fundamentals but you gotta put in work to learn how to apply them best.

inventory.title: Predictably Irrational
inventory.author: Dan Ariely
inventory.description: 10/10 - Very inspiring and interesting. Stuff makes ya think man.

inventory.title: Influence
inventory.author: Robert Cialdini
inventory.description: 100/10 - A chonker full of valuable insights and case studies. Easy to read, it just takes a while.

inventory.title: Design Sprint
inventory.author: Jake Knapp
inventory.description: 8/10 - Quick read and inspiring. Maybe a tad idealistic but the methods are grate and can be used on there own or when remixing the process.

inventory.title: How to Win Friends & Influence People
inventory.author: Dale Carnegie
inventory.description: 6/10 - Helpful tactics if you remember to apply them and chose the right moments.

inventory.title: Creativity Inc.
inventory.author: Edwin Catmull & Amy Wallace
inventory.description: 8/10 - Inspiring and makes you smile :)

inventory.title: Actionable Gamification
inventory.author: Yu-Kai Chou
inventory.description: 10/10 - Very actionable and covers a lot of ground which makes it valuable for most projects and situations.

inventory.title: The Theory of Fun
inventory.author: Raph Koster
inventory.description: 10/10 - Short but packed with very good points about what fun is and why learning rocks.

inventory.title: The Paradox of Choice
inventory.author: Barry Schwartz
inventory.description: 9/10 Very interesting, inspiring and entertaining

inventory.title: The Design of Everyday Things
inventory.author: Don Norman
inventory.description: 10/10 - Valuable fundamentals every designer should learn about.

inventory.title: Incognito
inventory.author: David Eagleman
inventory.description: 7/10 Not the most useful to UX but loads of examples about how our brain works that are very interesting to read

inventory.title: Continuous Discovery Habits
inventory.author: Teresa Torres
inventory.description: 10/10 - Very realistic, helpful and actionable examples about how to do product development in a structured, experiment based way while keeping the user is the center

inventory.title: Jobs to Be Done
inventory.author: Stephen Wunker, Jessica Wattman & David Farber
inventory.description: 5/10 - Nice to read a bit more about the theory but the TED talk already said it all.

inventory.title: Inspired
inventory.author: Marty Cagan
inventory.description: 4/10 - Not a bad book (easy and inspiring read) but at this point I feel like I already heard most of what this book is talking about.

inventory.title: Choice Hacking
inventory.author: Jennifer Clinehens
inventory.description: 7/10 - Pop-Science like. Not that deep but enjoyable, easy read and a good entry point for behavioural psychology.

inventory.title: UX for Lean Startups
inventory.author: Laura Klein
inventory.description: 7/10 - Super easy read with something for everyone. Not too deep, as its mostly case studies and short but good for an inspiration burst.

inventory.title: This is Service Design Thinking
inventory.author: Marc Stickdorn
inventory.description: 7/10 I think the first half could have been more condensed but it's a grate way of thinking with good methods to reference

inventory.title: Universal Methods of Design
inventory.author: Bella Martin & Bruce Hanington
inventory.description: 10/10 Really good to have on hand to know how to do a method but also to inspire which methods could be helpful in a given situation

inventory.title: OOUX Podcast
inventory.author: Sophia Prater
inventory.description: 10/10 - Recommending it all the time. Its educational every time and makes me want to go to the gym.

inventory.title: Growth.Design Newsletter
inventory.author: Dan Benoni & Louis-Xavier Lavallee
inventory.description: 10/10 - The only newsletter I ALWAYS read.

inventory.title: Nudge
inventory.author: Richard H. Thaler
inventory.description: Currently in progress

achievements.name: How to use the focus state to improve your TV App
achievements.description: After my first experience with designing for TV I was surprised and excited about the differences compared to designing for mobile or desktop. Hence I wrote down my learnings which got published under XXX

achievements.name: A compass for page layouts
achievements.description: While working on a design system, we wanted to include not only visual but also navigational guidelines. One of which got published under XXX

achievements.name: Design Sprint Masterclass Certificate
achievements.description: I am a big fan of the Design Sprint by Jake Knapp even though I like to bend the ruled. But I can do that now with confidence after learning the rules in their masterclass.

achievements.name: Scrum Product Owner Certificate
achievements.description: Though I never worked as a product owner, this class gave me a good understanding about working in a team with diverse roles.

achievements.name: OOUXer of the Month: May 2025
achievements.description: While taking the OOUX foundations course I was thrilled that my work for it got recognized and posted about. Though not a flashy achievement it is one I hold dear to my heart.

contact.title: LET'S EMBARK ON A QUEST TOGETHER
contact.description: Ready to bring your ideas to life? Let's connect and create something amazing together.
